subject: Re: [junit] multiple assertions
msgSnippet: I began with that approach and ended up wanting to tear my hair out. It s not a pretty solution.  Imagine you want to compare a collection of values.
messageBody:
I began with that approach and ended up wanting to tear my hair out.
It's not a pretty solution. Imagine you want to compare a collection of
values. Normally, you iterate through and test each one. Problem is
the first failure is all you get with JUnit, not giving you a clear
picture usually and forcing you to step outside the framework to
understand what's really going on. You can put this into multiple
tests, but then the framework isn't working for you any longer. It's
actually hindering your progress. I ended up modifying JUnit to allow
for multiple failures and am much happier having the option of fail-fast
versus many failures, choosing one over the other where appropriate.

http://www.gnufoo.org/junit/index.html#failures

-shane

On Friday, February 22, 2002, at 12:57 PM, Chris Eppstein wrote:

> A very simple approach to this is to use multiple test methods (one for
> each
> assertion that requires a result). Common code can be extracted to a
> separate method so it is easier to maintain.
>
> Is this approach infeasible for you?
